data.value: Any Series passed will have their name attributes used unless row or column names for the cross-tabulation are specified.
Any input passed containing Categorical data will have
of its categories included in the cross-tabulation, even if the actual data does not contain any instances of a particular category.
In the event that there aren't overlapping indexes an empty DataFrame will be returned.
Values to group by in the rows.

children.type_: array-like, Series, or list of arrays/Series

data.value: Values to group by in the columns.

children.type_: array-like, Series, or list of arrays/Series

data.value: Array of values to aggregate according to the factors. Requires
If passed, must match number of row arrays passed.
If passed, must match number of column arrays passed.
Name of the row/column that will contain the totals when margins is True.
Do not include columns whose entries are all NaN.
Normalize by dividing all values by the sum of values.
If passed 'index' will normalize over each row.
If passed 'columns' will normalize over each column.
Compute a simple cross tabulation of two (or more) factors. By default computes a frequency table of the factors unless an array of values and an aggregation function are passed.

data.out:
b   one        two
c   dull shiny dull shiny
a
bar    1     2    1     0
foo    2     2    1     2

data.value: Here 'c' and 'f' are not represented in the data and will not be shown in the output because dropna is True by default. Set dropna=False to preserve categories with no data.

data.out:
col_0  d  e
row_0
a      1  0
b      0  1

col_0  d  e  f
row_0
a      1  0  0
b      0  1  0
c      0  0  0

data.value: Reshape data based on column values.
Create a pivot table as a DataFrame.

signature.value: crosstab(index, columns, values=None, rownames=None, colnames=None, aggfunc=None, margins: 'bool' = False, margins_name: 'str' = 'All', dropna: 'bool' = True, normalize=False) -> 'DataFrame'
